Welcome to How To Cook That i'm Ann Reardon andÂ 
if you're new around here you might not know thatÂ Â

every year we make a gingerbread creation atÂ 
Christmas time ğŸ„ and this year is no exception,Â Â

so we're going to get on to that but before weÂ 
do let me show you some of the ones from previousÂ Â

years and just take a moment to wish you all myÂ 
wonderful subscribers a very Merry Christmas andÂ Â

thank you for your support throughout this yearÂ 
you guys are fantastic â¤ï¸ Now for this year'sÂ Â

gingerbread creations step one is to print and cutÂ 
out the template and any pieces that say join hereÂ Â

line them up and well you know what to do you guysÂ 
are smart. Step two is to make your dough this isÂ Â

a really easy recipe all you need to do is mixÂ 
all the ingredients together you can even justÂ Â

use a wooden spoon if you don't have a mixer forÂ 
that. I'll put all the recipe quantities and theÂ Â

template on my website howtocookthat.net when itÂ 
comes to the spices they are totally optional theyÂ Â

do not affect the texture of the dough in any wayÂ 
so you could leave them out all together you canÂ Â

add more you can change them up and customize itÂ 
to make your gingerbread taste just how you likeÂ Â

it. Once it's mixed it's really soft so now youÂ 
need to cover the bowl and put it in the fridgeÂ Â

for a few hours to let it firm up a bit. For stepÂ 
three you want to roll out the dough between twoÂ Â

sheets of baking paper and then take the topÂ 
one off sprinkle the top with flour and thisÂ Â

is just to stop the template from sticking to theÂ 
dough when you're cutting it out. Add the templateÂ Â

pieces into place and carefully cut around itÂ 
now for some pieces you want to leave a border ofÂ Â

gingerbread around the piece that you've cut outÂ 
and for other ones you want to take it away, letÂ Â

me just show you the difference of what happensÂ 
when you bake it with and without a border.Â Â

If i cut two circles and two number sevens soÂ 
you can see a curved edge and a straight edgeÂ Â

and then for one half i'll take all that spareÂ 
dough away and for the other i'll leave a borderÂ Â

around each piece. Halfway through bakingÂ 
you need to re-cut the ones with the borderÂ Â

and you can already see the difference ... theÂ 
ones without the border are rounded and the onesÂ Â

with the border are flatter and straighter edgesÂ 
which is ideal for walls where you need to joinÂ Â

them together. As well as the difference in theÂ 
edges there's also a difference in the spreadÂ Â

you'll see the ones without the border didn'tÂ 
spread as much so for any pieces that are joiningÂ Â

to another piece or it's important that they don'tÂ 
spread and they keep their exact shape to fit toÂ Â

something put a border of gingerbread while it'sÂ 
baking to keep it in place but to me those roundedÂ Â

edges they just look prettier and they look nicerÂ 
so if it's anything that's just on display it'sÂ Â

not joining to anything don't leave a border soÂ 
that the gingerbread can spread slightly and roundÂ Â

itself out because it looks nicer ğŸ˜Š The otherÂ 
thing to consider is how thick you roll your doughÂ Â

i'll show you two different thicknesses here, thisÂ 
is the thickness i like for walls or larger piecesÂ Â

that need structure and this is the thickness iÂ 
like for smaller pieces now obviously that's goingÂ Â

to bake a lot faster than this. When you're bakingÂ 
large thick pieces of gingerbread the trick isÂ Â

to bake it until you think it's done take it outÂ 
of the oven put another tray and baking paper onÂ Â

top and flip it over and then put it back in theÂ 
oven for another 10 minutes so that underside canÂ Â

really dry out. Once it is done and it's cooledÂ 
if it's still got a little bit of give in it youÂ Â

can just put it back into the oven again to dryÂ 
out or you can use this trick that i like to doÂ Â

which is to spread some compound melted chocolateÂ 
all over the back of the piece just to give it aÂ Â

little bit of extra strength or you could doÂ 
that if you just like the taste of chocolateÂ Â

with your gingerbread of course. Step four isÂ 
to decorate that's right it is much easier toÂ Â

decorate this one flat before you put it togetherÂ 
take some royal icing and draw an outline aroundÂ Â

the outside of your city and pipe a square forÂ 
each window. Now take some of that royal icingÂ Â

and add a little bit of water just a little bitÂ 
at a time because you can always add more butÂ Â

you can't take it out. Now if i stir this and thenÂ 
take the spoon out you can see that the icing isÂ Â

slowly melting down into a smooth flat surface andÂ 
that's the consistency that you're looking for.Â Â

Then we're going to add that onto the city andÂ 
spread it out right up to the border that we pipedÂ Â

and keep going until the whole thing is coveredÂ 
and then i like to just give it a little shakeÂ Â

just to help that icing settle out flat. To fillÂ 
smaller areas like the windows a piping bag or aÂ Â

plastic bag with the corner cut off makes itÂ 
much easier than using a spoon because it'sÂ Â

quite tricky the smaller it gets the more likelyÂ 
you are to make a mess now you want to repeat thatÂ Â

with all your other pieces and one other tipÂ 
you might need is if you want straight linesÂ Â

don't pipe with the bag touching the gingerbreadÂ 
hover it above and then as you move along thatÂ Â

line of icing kind of straightens itself out as itÂ 
falls into place. For all your smaller pieces pipeÂ Â

the outlines as shown on the template and thenÂ 
add some icing to fill it and use a toothpickÂ Â

or anything small that you've got to spread it outÂ 
into all those tricky little areas. If you're notÂ Â

confident with your drawing and piping abilitiesÂ 
place the template on top of the gingerbread pieceÂ Â

and using a sharp craft knife cut along the linesÂ 
on the template pushing through the paper and thatÂ Â

will leave a mark on your gingerbread that you canÂ 
then use to guide you when you pipe the outlines.Â Â

For some pieces you'll want to pipe in layersÂ 
so for example with the sheep we want to pipeÂ Â

a curvy pattern around the edge and then floodÂ 
fill in the middle spreading it all the way toÂ Â

the edge so it looks a bit like a cloud thenÂ 
pipe some more white on top and grab some blackÂ Â

and outline the feet and then pipe a littleÂ 
face on top. You should wait until the whiteÂ Â

is completely dry i was a bit impatient here soÂ 
you'll see later that black kind of bleeds intoÂ Â

the white a little bit. While i'm making theÂ 
sheep let me thank Big Farm Mobile Harvest forÂ Â

sponsoring this video, I'll put a link below whereÂ 
you can download the game for free. The game isÂ Â

a farm simulator game where you're in charge andÂ 
you need to harvest your crops and plant new onesÂ Â

and don't forget to collect your eggs and feed theÂ 
chickens. In December there are presents hiddenÂ Â

all over your farm they're really small but if youÂ 
look for them and find them you get extra rewardsÂ Â

like dog bones you can feed those to your dog,Â 
let me show you, there you go little doggie.Â Â

You can also join a co-op or make your ownÂ 
with friends and family so you can do someÂ Â

tasks together as a team. From time to time theyÂ 
run some in-game environmental initiatives like inÂ Â

September they had little tree saplings that youÂ 
had to get in the game and at the end of SeptemberÂ Â

they then donated enough money to plant 5000Â 
actual real trees not just in-game trees. I'llÂ Â

put a link below where you can download Big FarmÂ 
Mobile Harvest for free and start playing today.Â Â

Now back to our gingerbread house smash up someÂ 
clear hard-boiled lollies these ones that i've gotÂ Â

came in a bag but if yours didn't put them in aÂ 
bag before you put a hammer on them of course andÂ Â

then add those crumbs of smashed lollies into theÂ 
spaces on this piece so that it's going to look aÂ Â

bit like a sunburst â˜€ï¸ Make sure you load up eachÂ 
section really well because otherwise it'll be tooÂ Â

thin once you've done that pop it into the ovenÂ 
and let it melt. Did I mention to put nonstickÂ Â

baking paper underneath? I don't think i did ifÂ 
you don't do that it'll stick to the pan so makeÂ Â

sure you've got non-stick baking paper under it.Â 
Now if you take it out now it will be smooth orÂ Â

you can leave it in for a bit longer if you wantÂ 
it to bubble and then you'll get these bubblesÂ Â

in the window part which i like but don't leave itÂ 
too long or it will burn. If you want any parts ofÂ Â

your cookie gold you can't just brush luster dustÂ 
on it like we did with the chocolate balloon dogÂ Â

because unlike chocolate the luster dust doesn'tÂ 
stick to icing let me show you... if i brush someÂ Â

on it looks good but as soon as i brush it againÂ 
it brushes right off so what we need to do is addÂ Â

a little bit of vanilla essence to make a liquidÂ 
gold edible paint and then you can just paintÂ Â

that on wherever you want it. Once all your piecesÂ 
are decorated and ready you need to leave it forÂ Â

a couple of hours to make sure all that icing isÂ 
fully dry especially on those bigger pieces. WhileÂ Â

you're waiting if you need a last minute ChristmasÂ 
gift it's not too late to order on Amazon if youÂ Â

get in quickly they're still guaranteeing deliveryÂ 
before Christmas in the US and I think AustraliaÂ Â

you'll have to check on the website whereverÂ 
you're based. You could get Dave's novel The DeepÂ Â

Enders, my cookbook, great easy present ideasÂ 
you can wrap them up and give them to someoneÂ Â

on Christmas day. So once your pieces areÂ 
dry it's time for step 5 assembly ... startÂ Â

by putting together the light box at the back asÂ 
well as adding room for the lights this also addsÂ Â

stability to the backdrop so it's a good idea.Â 
This icing is just royal icing that i've addedÂ Â

a little bit of cocoa powder to for colour becauseÂ 
i didn't want white between the joins on this one.Â Â

Add the backdrop into place and you'll need toÂ 
support that with something behind it until it'sÂ Â

set so i'm just going to use a big jar that itÂ 
can lean on. Then add the strips to each sideÂ Â

these will join the two backdrops to give themÂ 
a bit of stability there but it also means thatÂ Â

there's a gap between them so you've got thatÂ 
distance. Put the front backdrop into place nowÂ Â

if you want lights which of course yes we doÂ 
want lights ğŸ’¡ now is the time to add them intoÂ Â

the light box and just thread the cord throughÂ 
and out the back so you can plug that in later.Â Â

Lay out your side pieces and pipe the icing alongÂ 
the base of where they will go then add the backÂ Â

of the building and pick up those two side piecesÂ 
and join them together. Near the back but notÂ Â

quite on it add more icing and add your windowÂ 
into place. You will be able to see this insideÂ Â

section here so neaten up your icing if it'sÂ 
bulging out like mine is and make sure it looksÂ Â

good. Before we do any more of the structure ofÂ 
this building we need to add the figures otherwiseÂ Â

it will be too hard to get your hands in. Add aÂ 
little scrap of gingerbread for support and yourÂ Â

little figure in front of it. Once they are all inÂ 
place you can then add the front of the buildingÂ Â

and then the roof on top. NowÂ 
you can decorate the roof withÂ Â

lollies or chocolate or whatever you want butÂ 
i decided to leave mine just plain gingerbread.Â Â

Now for the trees you will need a decent amountÂ 
of icing and some extra gingerbread scrapsÂ Â

behind them to keep them upright because they'reÂ 
quite top heavy so rest them against somethingÂ Â

as they set. Add your little donkey into place andÂ 
your sheep on the other side and then on the frontÂ Â

of the stable add a scrap of gingerbread justÂ 
underneath the awning there and plenty of icingÂ Â

and pop the star into place now you're eitherÂ 
going to need to stand there and hold thatÂ Â

to support it until it sets or put somethingÂ 
underneath it and do the same with your angel.
angels sing glory on high
peace be with you friends on this beautiful night.Â

wise men bring precious gifts for theÂ 
prince of peace as he sleeps on the hay

who knew that night would holdÂ 
the greatest story ever toldÂ

on this holiest of nights we let light intoÂ 
our lives this child our guide forevermore

Merry Christmas to all of you, a huge thankÂ 
you to my subscribers and my patrons forÂ Â

all of your support this yearÂ 
you guys are absolute legends IÂ Â

really appreciate it. God bless make it aÂ 
great week and i'll see you in the new year ğŸ’
